study_metadata.population: overweight patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus
study_metadata.inclusion_key: type 2 diabetes 30–60 years, BMI 25–30 kg/m2, HbA1c <8%
study_metadata.exclusion_key: other complications, insulin therapy, pregnancy, antioxidant supplements, red wine use

effects_by_outcome.name: FPG
effects_by_outcome.model_notes: adjusted for age, sex, baseline BMI

effects_by_outcome.name: Insulin
effects_by_outcome.model_notes: adjusted for age, sex, baseline BMI

evidence.snippet: resveratrol decreased fasting blood sugar (−7.97±13.6 mg/dL, p=0.05) compared with placebo.
Participants received 500 mg/d (twice a day) of resveratrol or placebo capsules for 8 weeks.
Insulin levels decreased by −0.97±1.91 µIU/mL (p=0.02) in the resveratrol group.

comment: Key glycemic effect found, but limited data.
comment_detailed: I searched the abstract, methods, and results sections for glycemic outcomes. The study reports a mean change in fasting blood sugar of −7.97 mg/dL (p=0.05) and insulin of −0.97 µIU/mL (p=0.02) after 8 weeks of 1000 mg/day resveratrol. Baseline and follow‑up means, SDs, and confidence intervals were not provided, so those fields are null. Randomization, blinding, and outcome measurement details are not fully described, so risk‑of‑bias fields are null. Page numbers are unavailable from the excerpt, so they are null. The evidence snippets capture the key numerical results and intervention details. Confidence is moderate due to missing numeric details and lack of full tables.}
